Upskill your communication

If you can’t articulate your value without buzzwords, how will you advocate for design in front of stakeholders?

Remember when the word “seamless” actually impressed people?

Me neither.

Designers over-rely on buzzwords to define who they are and what they do. You see it all over LinkedIn:

“Hi, I’m Alex. I’m a user-centered UX designer crafting intuitive and seamless experiences. Let’s chat!”

User-centered, intuitive, seamless… Does Alex actually know what those terms mean? Do you?

Dilution of meaning: The issue with buzzwords

Buzzwords are tossed around until they lose all meaning. That’s a problem for you as a designer, but also for everybody who works with you.

A weak vocabulary makes it harder to talk about the value of design with clients and colleagues.

The concepts just won’t get across the way you think they will. Misunderstandings will happen, and great design ideas will die to poor communication.

So let’s talk about some of those buzzwords, what they mean, what’s the problem with using them, and what to do instead.
